Problem:
Consider a complex function defined as \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \), where \( \omega \) is a real number and \( t \) is time. This function represents a point moving in a circle on the complex plane. We examine the effect of a Fourier transform, defined as \( \hat{z}(\omega') = \int_{-\infty}^\infty z(t)e^{-i\omega' t} dt \), on this function over the frequency domain \( \omega' \).

If \( z(t) \) is analyzed using the Fourier transform without any additional manipulation of the function, will \( \hat{z}(\omega') \) show a delta function at \( \omega' = \omega \)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of \( e^{i\omega t} \) is indeed a delta function centered at \( \omega \). This result directly follows from the properties of the Fourier transform, which maps each frequency component of \( z(t) \) to a delta function at its corresponding frequency in the frequency domain.
